#summary Instructions to enable nVidia's CUDA for GPUs

= Introduction =

The [http://code.google.com/p/gerardus/source/browse/#svn%2Ftrunk%2Fcpp%2Fsrc%2Fthird-party%2Fcquammen-Clarity Clarity library] used by Gerardus can be compiled with GPU support if you have an nVidia graphics card.

== Linux ==

 # Install the proprietary nVidia drivers for your distribution. In Ubuntu, e.g., install package ```nvidia-current```
{{{
 $ sudo apt-get install nvidia-current
}}}
 # Browse [http://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-downloads nVidia CUDA Downloads]. Click to download the latest CUDA Toolkit ([http://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-40 v4.0 RC2] as of this writing)
 # Click on "linux", or scroll down to [http://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-40#Linux CUDA for Linux]
 # Click on the CUDA Toolkit that corresponds to your distribution and system (e.g. [http://www.nvidia.com/object/thankyou.html?url=/compute/cuda/4_0/toolkit/cudatoolkit_4.0.17_linux_64_ubuntu10.10.run CUDA Toolkit for Ubuntu Linux 10.10 64 bit]). This will download a file e.g. `cudatoolkit_4.0.17_linux_64_ubuntu10.10.run`
 # Give execution permissions to the file
{{{
 $ chmod +x cudatoolkit_4.0.17_linux_64_ubuntu10.10.run
}}}
 # Run it as root, and hit ENTER when it asks for the install path if you are happy with it
{{{
 $ sudo ./cudatoolkit_4.0.17_linux_64_ubuntu10.10.run
